dcterms:title: Multiomics of Bohring-Opitz syndrome truncating ASXL1 mutations identify canonical and noncanonical Wnt signaling dysregulation
dcterms:abstract: ASXL1 (additional sex combs–like 1) plays key roles in epigenetic regulation of early developmental gene expression. De novo protein-truncating mutations in ASXL1 cause Bohring-Opitz syndrome (BOS; OMIM #605039), a rare neurodevelopmental condition characterized by severe intellectual disabilities, distinctive facial features, hypertrichosis, increased risk of Wilms tumor, and variable congenital anomalies, including heart defects and severe skeletal defects giving rise to a typical BOS posture. These BOS-causing ASXL1 variants are also high-prevalence somatic driver mutations in acute myeloid leukemia. We used primary cells from individuals with BOS (n = 18) and controls (n = 49) to dissect gene regulatory changes caused by ASXL1 mutations using comprehensive multiomics assays for chromatin accessibility (ATAC-seq), DNA methylation, histone methylation binding, and transcriptome in peripheral blood and skin fibroblasts. Our data show that regardless of cell type, ASXL1 mutations drive strong cross-tissue effects that disrupt multiple layers of the epigenome. The data showed a broad activation of canonical Wnt signaling at the transcriptional and protein levels and upregulation of VANGL2, which encodes a planar cell polarity pathway protein that acts through noncanonical Wnt signaling to direct tissue patterning and cell migration. This multiomics approach identifies the core impact of ASXL1 mutations and therapeutic targets for BOS and myeloid leukemias.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Generated data on gene regulatory changes using multiomics assays including ATAC-seq, DNA methylation, histone methylation binding, and transcriptome analysis

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: neural crest development
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: The canonical Wnt signaling regulates neural crest induction and is essential for development, particularly impacting neural crest cells which contribute to nervous system and craniofacial development.

obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:name: embryonic development
obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:description: Neural crest development is a crucial component of embryonic development, particularly affecting craniofacial and cardiac development in BOS patients.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: cell migration
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: The planar cell polarity pathway regulates polarized cellular migration and differentiation, particularly in neural development and tissue morphology.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: stem cell maintenance
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: Canonical Wnt signaling plays an important role in stem cell maintenance and differentiation of cells in adults.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: transcription
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: Nuclear β-catenin binds to TCF and LEF families to regulate transcription of Wnt pathway targets.

obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:name: neurulation
obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:description: Neural tube closure is a critical component of neurulation, regulated by planar cell polarity genes.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Bohring-Opitz syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Characterized by severe intellectual disabilities, distinctive facial features, hypertrichosis, increased risk of Wilms tumor, and variable congenital anomalies including heart defects and severe skeletal defects. Research shows truncating ASXL1 mutations drive strong cross-tissue effects disrupting multiple layers of the epigenome, causing broad activation of canonical Wnt signaling and upregulation of VANGL2.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: acute myeloid leukemia
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: ASXL1 truncating variants identified as high-prevalence somatic driver mutations in this cancer. These mutations are similar to those causing Bohring-Opitz syndrome and affect myeloid differentiation through epigenetic dysregulation.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: myelodysplastic syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Truncating mutations in ASXL1 are found in approximately 16% of cases and affect myeloid cell development through disruption of epigenetic regulation.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Wilms tumor
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Increased risk identified in Bohring-Opitz syndrome patients with ASXL1 mutations, requiring specific tumor surveillance protocols.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Vincristine
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Administered alongside Actinomycin D for Wilms tumor treatment in a BOS patient (patient 6) with ASXL1 mutation at amino acid 672. Treatment was completed years prior to sample collection for the study.
